questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following is the most common protein mutation seen in hypertrophic 
cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation:
The most common mutations in HCM are those affecting the myosin heavy chain. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant disease. In the majority of cases 
it is due to missense mutations in the following two sarcolemmal protein genes: • Myosin binding protein C (MYBC) • Beta myosin heavy chain (MYH7) Option B: Alpha-tropomyosin mutation is seen in HCM but is not common. Options C and D: Mutations in cardiac troponin C and titin are associated with dilated 
cardiomyopathy (DCM).

questions.question:
Question 2: A 19-year-old basketball player collapses during a match and regains consciousness several 
minutes later. He reveals that he has had similar episodes before. His older brother, a soccer 
player, had died suddenly at the age of 22 years during a soccer game due to a heart ailment. 
Which of the following is least likely to be found on echocardiography in this patient?

options.a: Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction
options.b: Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve
options.c: Mitral regurgitation with anteriorly directed regurgitant jet

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of exercise intolerance (syncope) in the patient and family history of 
sudden cardiac death in his elder brother at a young age is suggestive of hypertrophic 
cardiomyopathy (HCM). Mitral regurgitation with posteriorly directed regurgitant jet is usually 
seen on echocardiogram in HCM. ECG and echocardiogram are used to confirm the diagnosis of 
HCM. HCM is characterized by myofiber disarray in the heart, resulting in a hypertrophic myocardium. 
The hypertrophy leads to the following pathophysiological changes in HCM: • Diastolic dysfunction - presenting as exercise intolerance • Systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve • The hypertrophied muscles result in a narrow outflow tract • This leads to the production of a high-velocity jet pulling the mitral leaflets towards the septum 
posteriorly • SAM leads to mitral regurgitation • Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction Echocardiography features of HCM are as follows: 981 
Sold by @itachibot • Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm • Hypertrophied heart more confined to the interventricular septum resulting in banana-shaped 
ventricular cavity

questions.question:
Question 3: While evaluating a young man for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy you hear a harsh and late 
peaking systolic ejection murmur at the lower left sternal border. On performing which of the 
following maneuvers, the intensity of this murmur is expected to decrease?
questions.explanation:
Squatting increases the preload and afterload thereby decreasing the outflow obstruction and 
intensity of murmur in HCM. In HCM left ventricular size is small, thus the approximation of the interventricular septum with 
the mitral valve increases. The following mechanisms further increase this approximation and 
increase blood outflow obstruction and intensity of murmur: • A decrease in left ventricular cavity volume or pressure (decreased preload) • A decrease in systemic vascular resistance and/or arterial pressure (decreased afterload) • Increase in left ventricular contractility The image below shows a cross-section of a heart with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. questions.question:
Question 4: 976 
Sold by @itachibot A 20-year-old patient has been diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the 
following is not a major risk factor for sudden death in this condition?

options.c: Family history of sudden cardiac death

questions.explanation:
Atrial fibrillation in HCM is not associated with increased HCM-related mortality. It frequently 
accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost productivity, and impaired quality of life. Among HCM patients, the greatest risk for sudden cardiac death is seen in patients who have 
sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT). These patients must undergo placement of an implantable 
cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for secondary prevention.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 17-year-old boy presents with complaints of syncope. ECG is suggestive of LV hypertrophy. 
A doppler echocardiography revealed abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral 
valve. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Digoxin should be 
avoided as it may increase contractility and worsen obstruction. Drugs that can lead to possible aggravation of outflow tract obstruction and 
thus contraindicated in HCM are: • Digoxin • Inotropes • Nitrates • ACE inhibitors • Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg- nifedipine, amlodipine) Beta-blockers and verapamil are first-line agents in the treatment of HCM. Disopyramide and 
amiodarone are the preferred antiarrhythmic agents.

questions.question: Question 6: Which is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation:
Symptomatic atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained arrhythmia in hypertrophic 
cardiomyopathy (HCM). It frequently accounts for unexpected hospital admissions, lost 
productivity, and impaired quality of life. Treatment of atrial fibrillation in HCM: • Amiodarone - drug of choice • Disopyramide • Radiofrequency ablation for medically refractory cases • Anticoagulation to prevent embolic events Note: A sustained arrhythmia is one that lasts for >30 seconds. 983 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: You are counseling the parents of a 15-year-old boy who was recently diagnosed with 
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. What is the recommendation regarding his participation in 
sports?

options.a: Participation in competitive sports is not recommended
options.b: Only non-contact competitive sports are allowed
options.c: Non-contact competitive sports with beta-blocker therapy is allowed
options.d: High-intensity exercise is acceptable with verapamil therapy

questions.explanation:
Participation in competitive sports is not recommended for patients with hypertrophic 
cardiomyopathy. The following general measures are advised for patients with HCM: • Patients are advised against engaging in competitive athletics or vigorous physical activities • Maintaining low to moderate levels of exercise as a part of a healthy lifestyle has been proven to 
be beneficial • Adequate hydration at all times Note: Non-contact sports are those sports wherein the participants are physically separated with 
almost no physical contact (ex: tennis, badminton) between them. Contact sports involve some 
form of physical contact between the participants (ex: wrestling, boxing)

questions.question:
Question 8: A 65-year-old Japanese woman was brought to the emergency department with worsening 
angina and palpitations. Her physical examination was normal. ECG showed giant T wave 
inversions and coronary angiography was normal. Left ventriculography showed spade-like 
deformity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The presence of giant T wave inversions and spade-like deformity on left ventriculography points 
to a diagnosis of apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is also called Yamaguchi syndrome. It is characterized by 
hypertrophy of the myocardium, predominantly in the left ventricular apex. It was first described 
in the Japanese population and is uncommon in other populations. The symptoms are milder and the risk of sudden cardiac death is lower than in the traditional 
septal form of HCM. The image below shows the ace of spades appearance on left ventriculography: The image below shows the ace of spades appearance on echocardiography with massive 
hypertrophy of the apex and relative sparing of the base: 984 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: Two brothers were arguing over a property dispute when the elder of the two complained of 
chest pain and collapsed and was later declared brought dead by the hospital. His family says 
he was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. What is 
the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of sudden heart failure in a previously healthy person under a stressful 
situation is suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or 
stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spams 
due to a catecholamine surge during stress. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients 
can present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain. ECHO reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a Takotsubo 
(pot for catching octopus). The ECG changes can mimic myocardial infarction but changes extend 
beyond a particular coronary arterial territory. Coronary angiography, therefore, may be needed 
to rule out coronary occlusion. (Option B) It is a self-limiting disorder resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good. The image below shows left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning resembling 
a Takotsubo pot. 985 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option A: Infective cardiomyopathy: The most common causes of infective myocarditis are viral 
infections and the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, which is associated with Chagas' disease. Acute 
viral myocarditis often presents with symptoms and signs of heart failure, although it can also 
manifest as chest pain and show electrocardiogram (ECG) changes resembling pericarditis or 
acute myocardial infarction. In Chagas' disease, specific features include abnormalities in the 
conduction system, particularly dysfunction of the sinus node and AV node, as well as the right 
bundle branch block. Option C: Dilated cardiomyopathy: It is the most common cardiomyopathy and is predominantly 
characterised by systolic dysfunction. Though it may present acutely, it progresses chronically. 
The familial form is due to mutations in TTN gene which encode the sarcomeric protein titin. 
Other etiologocal agents include alcohol, infective myocarditis, doxorubicin, hemochromatosis 
and sarcoidosis. Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most 
common genetic cardiovascular disorder and is a prominent cause of sudden death before the age 
of 35 years. Family history is commonly present, a sarcomere mutation is present in ~50% of 
patients. Sudden death can be due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation. Risk factors 
for sudden death in this disease include young age, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, failure 
of blood pressure to increase during exercise, recent (within 6 months) syncope, ventricular wall 
thickness >3 cm, and possibly the severity of LV outflow obstruction.

questions.question:
Question 10: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. 
What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is the probable diagnosis when the observed myocardial stunning 
pattern does not match ECG changes. Myocardial stunning is a state where certain segments of the myocardium (usually corresponding 
to an area of major coronary occlusion) show forms of contractile abnormality (dysfunction) on 
echocardiography. 986 
Sold by @itachibot In Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, while the ECG changes mimic a myocardial infarction(MI), the left 
ventricular dysfunction extends well beyond the distribution of a specific coronary artery. Thus, 
the myocardial stunning pattern might not fully match the ECG. Ventriculography shows apical 
dilation with basal contraction. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy occurs typically in older women and is associated with a sudden 
increase in emotional or physical stress, presenting with hypotension, chest pain with ECG 
changes of acute MI, and pulmonary edema. Its also known as apical ballooning syndrome or 
acute stress-induced cardiomyopathy. Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction with reduced 
contractility and ejection fraction, most commonly seen in amyloidosis, and enlarged ventricles on 
imaging with low-voltage ECG complexes. Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is a type of familial dilated 
cardiomyopathy (DCM), having defects in desmosomal proteins, affecting the ventricles showing 
thin ventricular walls on Echo, epsilon waves, and low voltage ECG complexes. Option D: Pericardial tamponade is characterized by hypotension, muffled heart sounds and 
increased jugular venous pressure with muffled heart sounds with total electrical alternans and 
sinus tachycardia in ECG.

questions.question:
Question 11: 978 
Sold by @itachibot A 17-year-old Chinese boy presented with prolonged fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling 
in the legs. His echocardiography was suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the 
following nutritional deficiencies can explain his condition?
questions.explanation:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency. It is 
endemic dilated cardiomyopathy that affects children and women of childbearing age in some 
areas in China. The nutritional deficiencies that can lead to cardiomyopathy are: • Thiamine • Selenium • Carnitine • Calcium • Phosphate • Magnesium

questions.question: Question 13: In which of the following patients, the risk of developing peripartum cardiomyopathy is less?

options.a: A 26-year-old pregnant woman with an obstetric score of G2P1

questions.explanation:
Low parity is not a risk factor for peripartum cardiomyopathy. Increased parity is a risk factor. Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. It develops during 
the last month of pregnancy or within the first 5 months following delivery. The risk factors are: • Increased maternal age • Increased parity • Twin pregnancy • Malnutrition • Use of tocolytic therapy for premature labor • Preeclampsia or toxemia of pregnancy

questions.question:
Question 14: A young male patient presents with progressive dyspnea and weakness. He gives a history of 
fever, myalgia, and sore throat one week ago. To further evaluate him as per Dallas criteria, 
which of the following tests need to be performed?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infective myocarditis. The Dallas criteria used for the 
diagnosis of myocarditis is based on endomyocardial biopsy. It is used to define the disease. Active myocarditis is defined as an inflammatory infiltrate of the myocardium with necrosis 
and/or degeneration of adjacent myocytes not typical of the ischemic damage associated with 
coronary artery disease. Borderline myocarditis is the term used when the inflammatory infiltrate is too sparse or myocyte 
injury is not demonstrated.

questions.question: Question 15: Which is the most common infective cause of myocarditis?
questions.explanation:
The most common infective cause of myocarditis is Trypanosoma cruzi causing Chagas disease. Infective myocarditis is most commonly associated with viruses (adenovirus, coxsackie B virus, 
HHV-6) and the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi. The most common noninfective cause of myocarditis is sarcoidosis.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and 
prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed systolic anterior motion of the 
mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and 
which of the following are true regarding the management?
questions.explanation:
988 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario of a young patient with a history of sudden collapse following physical 
activity along with ECG findings of V5, V6 inversion, and prominent inverted T-waves, and 2D 
echocardiography showing the systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet point toward a 
diagnosis of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM). In HCM, clinical examination may reveal pulsus bisferiens and an ejection systolic murmur that 
increases on standing. Beta-blockers and implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICD) are used in the management. HCM is a leading cause of sudden death in young. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant 
pattern with variable penetrance. HCM is characterized by the thickening of the septal 
myocardium below the aortic valve leading to obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract. Symptoms: • Exertional dyspnea • Syncope • Angina, palpitations, cardiac arrhythmias • Sudden cardiac death (particularly during or after intense physical activity) Examination: • Systolic ejection murmur best heard at the apex or lower left sternal border • Holosystolic murmur from mitral regurgitation • Sustained apex beat • S4 gallop • Paradoxical split of S2 • Pulsus bisferiens: LV outflow obstruction causes a sudden quick rise of the pulse followed by a 
slower longer rise. ECG findings: • Left axis deviation • P wave abnormalities • Prominent abnormal Q waves • Deeply inverted T waves Echocardiography findings: • LV wall thickness 15 mm • Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet • Mitral regurgitation Treatment: • Beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers are the first-line treatment • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) - indicated when the history of cardiac arrest or 
sustained ventricular tachycardia is present 989
